title: 106_hr263
content: The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes an excise tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payments in factoring transactions, as outlined in Chapter 55 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardships. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardships. The term structured settlement payment rights refer to periodic payments of damages or compensation that are excludable from gross income under specific sections, and payable by a party to the suit or agreement or by a person who has assumed liability for such payments through a qualified assignment. The term 'structured settlement payment rights' refers to the rights to receive payments under a structured settlement. A 'structured settlement factoring transaction' is the transfer of these payment rights for consideration. The 'factoring discount' is the excess amount paid by the acquirer compared to the total structured settlement payments acquired. The 'relevant court or administrative authority' is the entity responsible for overseeing these transactions. The court or administrative authority with jurisdiction over the underlying action or claim of the structured settlement is responsible for overseeing structured settlement factoring transactions. Coordination with sections 72, 130, and 461(h) requirements is maintained even after a factoring transaction occurs. The court or administrative authority overseeing structured settlement factoring transactions ensures coordination with sections 72, 130, and 461(h) requirements. The transaction does not affect the application of provisions to the parties involved, including an assignee under a qualified assignment. The Secretary is authorized to prescribe regulations for clarifying the treatment of amounts received by the structured settlement recipient in such transactions. Information reporting requirements are amended to include new section in the tax code. "SEC. 6050T. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR STRUCTURED SETTLEMENT FACTORING TRANSACTIONS." In structured settlement factoring transactions, the person making the payments must report and provide written statements to the acquirer of the payment rights as required by section 6041 or regulations prescribed by the Secretary. This reporting obligation applies instead of other provisions in this part. The reporting obligations for structured settlement payments in factoring transactions do not fall under section 3405 withholding provisions. The term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights' includes persons described in section 7701(a)(1). Clerical amendments have been made to the Code. The amendments in Chapter 55 introduce reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions under Sec. 6050T of the Internal Revenue Code. These amendments apply to transactions occurring after the enactment of the Act.
